metadata.title: High and low temperature properties of nano-particles/polymer modified asphalt

High and low temperature properties of nano-particles/polymer modified asphalt

Zhang Hong-liang a,⇑, Su Man-man a, Zhao Shi-feng b, Zhang Yong-ping c, Zhang Zeng-ping a aKey Laboratory for Special Area Highway Engineering of Ministry of Education, Chang’an University, Xi’an, Shaanxi 710064, PR China bChangchun Municipal Engineering Design and Research Institute, Changchun, Jilin 130033, PR China cHangzhou Highway Administration Bureau, Hangzhou, Zhejiang 310004, PR China
h i g h l i g h t s
Three kinds of nano-particles/polymer systems were proposed to modify SK-70 asphalt. Influences of nano-particles/polymer on the properties of SK-70 asphalt were tested with TFOT, DSR and BBR tests. Morphologies of modified asphalts and SK-70 asphalt were measured with SEM. The chemical bondings of modified asphalts and SK-70 asphalt were analyzed through FTIR.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 8 December 2015 Received in revised form 15 March 2016 Accepted 21 March 2016
Keywords: Modified asphalt Nano-particles Polymer Properties Morphology Modification mechanism
a b s t r a c t
At present, most asphalts and modified asphalts cannot meet requirements of both high temperature stability and low temperature cracking resistance simultaneously. Hence, the objective of this paper is to find new modification system to improve the high and low temperature properties of SK-70 base asphalt. In this paper, nano-zinc oxide (nano-ZnO) particles, nano-titanium dioxide (nano-TiO2) particles, nano-calcium carbonate (nano-CaCO3) particles, styrene-butadiene-styrene (SBS) and styrene-butadienerubber (SBR) were selected as modifiers. The modified asphalt samples with three or two kinds of modifiers were prepared, and the softening point, ductility and penetration of modified asphalt samples were measured and compared. Eventually, three optimal nano-particles/polymer modification systems for SK-70 base asphalt including 3%nano-ZnO/0.5%nano-TiO2/3.7%SBS, 5%nano-ZnO/4.2%SBS, 5%nanoCaCO3/4%SBR were proposed. To study the effects of these three optimal modification formulations on high and low temperature properties of base asphalt, dynamic shear rheometer (DSR), thin film oven test (TFOT), and beam bending rheometer (BBR) tests were conducted on the asphalt of SK-70 and the nanoparticles/polymer modified asphalts. The micro-morphology of SK-70 and the modified asphalts was examined using scanning electron microscope (SEM) and the reactions between modifiers and SK-70 base asphalt were studied by infrared spectrum instrument. From the test results, it was observed that the nano-materials were well dispersed in base asphalt, and could increase the dispersibility of polymer in base asphalt and improve the compatibility between polymer and base asphalt. Furthermore, the nano-materials could improve the high and low temperature properties of SK-70 base asphalt. Additionally, the results also revealed that for polymer modified asphalts the physical reaction between polymers and asphalt played the dominant role in the modification process, while for nano-particles/ polymer modified asphalts, both physical and chemical reaction occurred in the modification process.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Asphalt binder is one of critical components in the construction of asphalt pavement. Over 90% of the freeways in China are paved with asphalt. The regions with hot summer and cold winter have
more strict requirements on asphalt properties. However, it is not easy to find the base asphalt which can meet the requirements of both high temperature stability and low temperature cracking resistance simultaneously. Therefore, it’s necessary to find some approaches to improve these properties of base asphalt.
The polymer modification is the most widely used approach to improve the properties of base asphalt. Currently, styrenebutadiene-styrene (SBS), styrene-butadiene-rubber (SBR) and
polyethylene (PE) have been become popular modifiers to improve the elasticity and ductility of asphalt pavement [1]. Studies conducted by Khodaii and Mehrara [2], Lu and Isacsson [3] showed that SBS increased the binder elasticity at high temperatures, and asphalt modified with SBS had better permanent deformation susceptibility compared to unmodified asphalt. Li et al. [4] evaluated the low temperature rheological performance (LTRP) of SBS modified asphalt through dynamic shear rheometer (DSR) test, the results showed that SBS could improve the LTRP significantly when the temperature ranged from 10 C to 10 C. Good properties of SBS modified asphalt were due to that SBS could absorb lowmolecular weight oil fraction of asphalt and brought asphalt more stable structures. Wang et al. [5] tested the influence of SBR polymer on 160# base asphalt, the ductility at 5 C increased about 28 cm compared to that of base asphalt. Becker et al. [6] reported that SBR polymers increased the ductility of asphalt, which could allow the pavement to be more flexible and crack resistance at low temperature. PE is one of the most popular plastics and is renowned for its good fatigue resistance [7,8]. Punith [9] proved that the addition of PE could reduce creep rate of asphalt mixture at high temperature. The researches of Jun et al. [10] and Nuñez et al. [11] indicated that PE could also increase the complex modulus of base asphalt and reduce the susceptibility of the asphalt to rutting. From the review of polymer modified asphalt, it could be concluded that SBS could improve high and low temperature properties to some extent. However, the properties of SBS modified asphalt are not good enough to resist very high temperature and very low temperature at the same time. Therefore, severe rutting or cracking sometimes occur in SBS modified asphalt pavement in the area where is very hot in summer and very cold in winter. Although SBR can improve the rutting resistance of base asphalt to a large extent, fail to improve the high temperature properties of base asphalt significantly. For PE polymer, the modification effect on base asphalt is in contradiction to that of SBR.
The nano-material modification is another important approach to improve the properties of asphalt binder [12]. Many researches about nano-material modified asphalt had been done and considerable findings were obtained. Sarsam [13] suggested that nanoparticles could strongly absorb the asphalt, and a special physicochemical interaction occurred, as a result the asphalt temperature sensitivity was changed. Ye [14] reported the influence of nanotitanium dioxide (nano-TiO2) particles on the temperature properties of AH-70 base asphalt, and found that softening points of the modified asphalt with 0.5% nano-TiO2 increased by 5 C, the ductility at 5 C decreased about 2.25 cm compared to those of base asphalt. The study of Tanzadeh et al. [15] illustrated that nanoTiO2 could improve the capability of rutting resistance of asphalt binder. Sun et al. [16] showed that nano-TiO2 modified asphalt possessed more stable ductility and smaller softening point changing ratio than base asphalt, and it could be concluded that nano-TiO2 particles actively enhanced the photooxidation properties of asphalt and nano-TiO2 modified asphalt was capable of resisting photooxidation aging. Arabani et al. [17] investigated the effect of nano-zinc oxide (nano-ZnO) on improving mechanical properties of hot mix asphalt (HMA) through laboratory experiments, and
the results showed that nano-ZnO particles could decreased the permanent deformation of HMA pavement. Liu et al. [18] showed that surface modified nano-ZnO particles had satisfied dispersion in asphalt and could improve the ultraviolet aging resistance of asphalt. The researches on nano-calcium carbonate (nano-CaCO3) modified asphalt indicated that softening points ofmodified asphalt with 5%nano-CaCO3 increased by 1.7 C, and enhanced the ruttingresistance of base asphalt [19,20]. Moreover, compared to other nano-materials, nano-CaCO3 is fairly inexpensive and natural abundant. Many researchers have studied performance and rheological properties of nano-montmorillonite (nano-MMT) modified asphalt [21–24]. Yu et al. [25] indicated that the addition of nano-MMT was able to increase the softening point and viscosity of the asphalt. The results of Zhang et al. [26] demonstrated that nano-MMT as an additive could increase ductility retention rates of asphalt and improve the aging resistance of asphalt. Zhang et al. [27] conducted research on nano-ferroferric oxide (nano-Fe3O4) modified asphalt, the softening point of modified asphalt increased by 2.5 C and the ductility at 5 C increased by 2 cm than those of base asphalt. Though these nano-additives effectively improve the cracking or rutting resistance of asphalt pavement, unfortunately, pure nanomaterial modified asphalt still can’t meet the strict requirements of the area where is very hot in summer and very cold in winter.
For most pure polymer modifiers, thermo-dynamical incompatibility with asphalt is one of the major shortcomings, which results in delamination of the composite during thermal storage. However, nano-materials can improve the compatibility between polymer and asphalt, so nano-material/polymer modified asphalt also becomes more and more popular. Nano-CaCO3, nano-ZnO and nano-MMT were combined with SBS to modify base asphalt by several researchers [28–30]. Jerome [31] discussed the influence of nano-clays on the rheological properties of SBS modified asphalt and base asphalt. Kebritchi et al. [32] initially coated polymers on the surface of nano-CaCO3 and this nano-particle/polymer composite was employed as modifier and the rheological properties of the modified asphalt were reported. Compared to pure nano-materials or pure polymer modifier, nano-particle/polymer composite exhibited better effects on the mechanics properties of asphalt.
This paper aimed to put forward new nano-particles/polymer composite modification systems which can meet the requirement of the area where is very hot in summer and very cold in winter. Polymers including SBS, SBR and PE, and nano-materials including nano-CaCO3, nano-ZnO, nano-TiO2, nano-Fe3O4 and nano-MMT were used to modify SK-70 base asphalt. The modified asphalt samples with three or two kinds of modifiers were prepared, and the penetration, softening point and ductility of these samples were measured and compared. Several optimal nano-particles/ polymer modification formulations were selected to modify SK-70 base asphalt. Then the effect of these new modification formulations on the high and low temperature properties of SK-70 base asphalt was studied by thin film oven test (TFOT), DSR and beam bending rheometer (BBR) tests. Furthermore, the micromorphology and modification mechanism of nano-particles/ polymer modified asphalt were investigated by scanning electron microscope (SEM) and fluorescence microscope techniques.
2. Experimental design
2.1. Materials
The SK-70 base asphalt from South Korea was used in this study and its properties were shown in Table 1. The properties of nano-material modifiers including nano-CaCO3, nano-ZnO, nano-TiO2, nano-Fe3O4 and nano-MMT were shown in Table 2. And the properties of polymer modifiers were shown in Table 3.
2.2. Selection of optimal nano-particles/polymer modification systems
In this study, the optimal nano-particles/polymer modification systems were selected as follows.
(1) Selection of nano-material modifiers
Nano-CaCO3, nano-ZnO, nano-TiO2, nano-Fe3O4 and nano-MMT was added to SK-70 base asphalt at the same concentrations of 5 wt%, respectively. The softening point, ductility and penetration of these nano-material modified asphalts were measured and compared. The nano-material which had better effect on increasing the softening point and ductility of based asphalt was selected.
(2) Selection of polymer modifiers
In this step, SBR concentrations in the base asphalt were chosen as 3 wt%, 4 wt% and 5 wt%. SBS concentrations in base asphalt were chosen as 3.7 wt%, 4.2 wt% and 4.7 wt%. PE concentrations in base asphalt were chosen as 4%wt, 5 wt% and 6 wt%. The softening point, ductility and penetration of these polymer modified asphalts were measured and compared. The polymer which had better improvement effect on properties of SK-70 base asphalt was selected.
(3) Selection of nano-particles/polymer modification systems
Several modification systems which include three or two kinds of modifiers were designed according to the selected modifiers, and the softening point, ductility and penetration were measured and compared. At last, the optimal modification systems were finally selected according to the improvement on the properties of SK-70 base asphalt and the cost of modification systems.
2.3. Preparation of nano-particles/polymer modified asphalt samples
The procedures below are followed in achieving nano-materials surfacemodified by silane coupling agent: (a) under room temperature (about 25 C), put a amount of nano-materials into flask, then start-up the rotor of mechanical mixer, and at the same time pour silane coupling agent into flask. Silane coupling agent is added to the nano-materials at the ratio of 2 wt%; (b) heat up the flask to 100– 150 C and keep stirring for 40–60 min; (c) turn off the mechanical mixer and cool the mixture at room temperature. So far, the surface-modified nano-material is obtained.
The procedures of preparing the formulations are as follows: (a) slowly warm SK-70 base asphalt in an oven until it becomes a uniform liquid; (b) desired amount of nano-material and polymer are added slowly to the liquid asphalt, then keep stirring the mixture at temperature of 160 C for 20 min at the rotation speed of 2000 rpm; (c) keep stirring the mixture at the temperature of 170 C for 40 min using high shear mixer with rotation speed of 4500 rpm.
2.4. Instrument and performance test
2.4.1. Conventional bitumen test In order to compare physical properties between SK-70 base asphalt and nanoparticles/polymer modified asphalts, penetration (0.1 mm at 25 C, 100 g, 5 s), softening point (R&B) and ductility (5 cm/min,5 C) of them were measured in accordance with specification of China (JTG E-20-2011) [33].
2.4.2. Aging test According to ASTM-D1754 [34] standard, TFOT of base asphalt and the optimal nano-particles/polymer modified asphalts were performed with HAD-82A thin film oven manufactured by Beijing Hengaode Technology Ltd.
2.4.3. DSR and BBR tests DSR test and BBR test were conducted to evaluate the rheological property of base asphalt and the optimal nano-particles/polymer modified asphalts at high temperature and low temperature, respectively. According to the test standard of ASTM-D 4402 [35], DSR test was conducted at five temperatures of 64 C, 70 C, 76 C, 82 C and 88 C with an AR1500ex dynamic shear rheometer instrument which manufactured by Shanghai Yulai Ltd. According to the ASTM-D6648 standard [36], the BBR test was conducted at temperatures of 12 C, 18 C, and 24 C with the TE-BBR instrument manufactured by YSA.
2.4.4. Micro-morphology and modification mechanism characterization The micro-morphologies of SK-70 base asphalt, SBS modified asphalt, SBR modified asphalt and the optimal nano-particles/polymer modified asphalts were tested on a PHILIPS XIJ30-ESEM manufactured in Holland. The modification mechanism of nano-particles/polymer modified asphalts was studied with Nicolet-740 which with wavelengths ranging from 400 cm 1 to 4000 cm 1 infrared spectrum instrument manufactured by Thermo Nicolet Corporation of USA.
And in the tests listed above, for base asphalt and every kind of modified asphalt, five replicates were prepared in the same test condition.

sections.heading: 3.1. Selection of optimal nano-particles/polymer modification systems
sections.text:
(1) Step 1: selection of nano-material modifiers Table 4 shows the penetrations, softening points and ductilities of nano-material modified asphalts and SK-70 base asphalt. And
Table 4 indicates that the penetration of asphalt decreases after nano-materials are added. All of the nano-material particles can improve the softening point of SK-70 base asphalt, and the order of improvement effect of nano-material on softening point is nano-TiO2 > nano-ZnO > nano-CaCO3 > nano-MMT > nano-Fe3O4. And the softening point of nano-TiO2 modified asphalt reaches to 61.7 C, which increases by 11.9 C than that of SK-70 base asphalt. Nano-ZnO has the best improvement effect on the ductility of SK70 base asphalt and the ductility of nano-ZnO reaches to 7.8 cm, which increases by 1 cm than that of SK-70 base asphalt. NanoTiO2 has slight improvement effect on the ductility of SK-70 asphalt. Moreover, nano-CaCO3, nano-Fe3O4 and nano-MMT have negative effect on the ductility of SK-70 asphalt. According to the analysis above, nano-ZnO, nano-TiO2 and nano-CaCO3 materials were selected as nano-material modifiers.
(2) Step 2: selection of polymer modifiers
Table 5 shows the penetrations, softening points and ductilities of polymer modified asphalts and SK-70 asphalt. Obviously, the improvement effect of SBR on the ductility of SK-70 asphalt is far superior to that of SBS and PE. In addition, SBR also increases the softening point of SK-70 asphalt to some extent. SBS shows the best improvement effect on the softening point of SK-70 asphalt in three polymers, and it also has good improvement effect on the ductility of SK-70 asphalt. Hence, SBR and SBS were selected as polymer modifiers. Moreover, with increasing of mixing amount of SBR, the softening point of SBR modified asphalt first increase and then decrease, and exhibits a peak at the content of 4%. The ductility of SBR modified asphalt increases with increasing of mixing amount of SBR, and the value achieves above 100 cm at both content of 4% and 5%. Hence, 4% is the optimal content for SBR. For SBS modified asphalt, the ductility and softening point reaches a peak at the content of 4.2% and 4.7%, respectively. And the softening point of SBS modified asphalt at the content of 4.2% is close to that of at the content of 4.7%. Hence, 4.2% is regard as the optimal content for SBS in base asphalt.
(3) Step 3: selection of nano-particles/polymer modification systems with three kinds of modifiers
Nano-CaCO3, nano-ZnO, nano-TiO2, SBS and SBR were selected as modifiers from Step 1 and Step 2. Obviously, it’s extremely wasteful and not realistic to complete an entire factor combination experiment to determine the optimal nano-particles/polymer modification system for SK-70 base asphalt. Orthogonal Experiment Design (OED) can reduce the number of experiments greatly and enhance the working efficiency. So, the OED method was used in this paper. The application steps of OED were as follows: first of
all, selection of factors. Three factors were selected in Table 6, in which factor A including nano-ZnO and nano-CaCO3 were used to improve high and low temperature properties of base asphalt, factor B including nano-ZnO and nano-TiO2 were used to further enhance the high temperature properties of base asphalt and factor C including SBS and SBR were used to decrease the sensitivity of base asphalt under low temperature. Secondly, selection of levels. For every factor in Table 6, three levels were selected based on the prices of modifiers and the influences of modifiers on the properties of asphalt. For factor A, the prices of nano-ZnO and nanoCaCO3 were around 1500 $/t and 200 $/t, respectively. Then, combining the prices of nano-materials and the improvement effect of nano-ZnO, nano-CaCO3 on the softening point and ductility of base asphalt, the levels of nano-ZnO were determined as 2%, 3% and 4%, the levels of nano-CaCO3 were determined as 4%, 5%, 6% or 2%, 3%, 4%. Compared to nano-ZnO the price of nano-TiO2 was relative expensive (about 2700 $/t). And in order to control the total cost of modification system, the levels of nano-TiO2 in factor B were determined lower than those of nano-ZnO. And the levels of nano-ZnO and nano-TiO2 in factor B were determined as 2%, 3%, 4% and 0, 0.5%, 1% (see Table 6), respectively. So the two different group levels of nano-CaCO3 in factor A were determined. And the higher levels and low levels were used with nano-ZnO and nanoTiO2 in factor B together, respectively.
According to Table 6, the modified asphalt systems were prepared and their softening points, ductilities and penetrations were measured. Due to the limitation of the length of this paper, only the test results of nano-ZnO/nano-TiO2/SBS modified asphalt samples were given (see Table 7).
Based on the test results listed in Table 7, the influence of modifiers concentrations on softening point, ductility and penetration of asphalt were shown in Fig. 1. According to Fig. 1, the optimal concentrations of nano-ZnO, nano-TiO2 and SBS in base asphalt were determined as 3%(L2), 0.5%(L2) and 3.7%(L3), respectively. And for the other modification systems with three modifiers, the optimal concentrations of modifiers were determined in the similar way. Finally, 6 modification systems (from 1# to 6#) were selected and listed in Table 8.

(4) Step4: selection of nano-particles/polymer modification systems with two kinds of modifiers
Tables 9 and 10 show the test design of nano-particles/polymer modification systems with two kinds of modifiers. According to
these two tables, the softening point, ductility and penetration of modified asphalts were measured. Table 11 displays the test results of modified asphalts. By comparing the improvement effects of different modification systems on base asphalt, the modification formulations of 5% nano-CaCO3 + 4%SBR, 5% nano-ZnO + 4.2%SBS and 3% nano-ZnO + 4%SBR were selected.
(5) Step5: determination of optimal nano-particles/polymer modification systems
According to the results got from Step 3 and Step 4, nine different modification systems with two or three kinds of modifiers were listed in Table 8, and the cost of every modification system was given also in Table 8. It can be found that the ranking of the softening point values is 8# > 1# > 6# > 5# > 3# > 7# > 9# > 2# > 4#, and the ranking of the ductility values is 9# > 7# > 6# > 2# > 4# > 8# > 1# > 3# > 5#, and the ranking of every modification cost in per ton of base asphalt is 7#＜ 6#＜ 5#＜ 4#＜ 9#＜ 3#＜ 2# ＜ 1#＜ 8#. According to these rankings, threemodification formulations including 3% nano-ZnO + 0.5% nano-TiO2 + 3.7%SBS (1#), 5% nano-CaCO3 + 4%SBR (7#) and 5% nano-ZnO + 4.2%SBS (8#) were proposed finally.
Generally, SBS and SBR are the most common modifiers used in the freeway construction in China. The concentrations of SBS and SBR are about 5% and 4% respectively, and the costs of SBS and SBR in per ton of asphalt are about 120$ and 80$ respectively. The costs of three optimal modifications are about 138$ (1#), 89 $ (7#) and 170$ (8#), respectively. Obviously, the cost of 1#
modification system is a little higher than that of SBS, the cost of 7# modification system is a little higher than that of SBR. However, the softening point of 1# modified asphalt reaches 80.3 C compared to 70.2 C of SBS modified asphalt, and the ductility of 1# modified asphalt is more 7.5 cm than that of SBS modified asphalt. In addition, the softening point of 7# modified asphalt achieves 72.1 C compared to 58.1 C of SBR modified asphalt. Although the costs of 1# and 7# modifications are higher, this may be compensated by the superior properties in terms of higher softening point and higher ductility. Although the cost of 8# modification is higher than those of SBS and SBR modified asphalt to a large extent, the softening point and ductility of 8# modified asphalt increased by 24 C and 12 cm than that of SBR modified asphalt, respectively. Therefore, the cost of 8# modification is also acceptable according to the dramatic improvements it brings for the properties of base asphalt.

sections.heading: 3.2. Evaluation of high and low temperature properties of nanoparticles/polymer modified asphalts
3.2.1. Conventional bitumen test analysis
sections.text: Table 12 shows the effects of nano-particles and polymer modifier on the penetration, softening point and ductility of base asphalt. It can be seen that both the ductilities and softening points of three formulations increase significantly compared with those of SK-70 base asphalt. The ductilities of three formulations increase at least by 4.6 times compared with that of base asphalt. The highest ductility value of modified asphalts is above 100 cm, which is achieved by adding nano-CaCO3 particles and SBR to the base asphalt. For the softening points, the 8# modified asphalt exhibits the greatest change compared with the base asphalt, which is 30 C. Simultaneously, the penetrations of nano-particles/polymer modified asphalts decrease significantly compared with that of base asphalt.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Aging property analysis
sections.text:
Table 13 shows the TFOT results of base asphalt and 1#, 7#, 8# modified asphalts. As shown in Table 13, the mass losses of
nano-particles/polymer modified asphalts are less than that of SK-70 base asphalt. The mass loss of modified asphalts is well below the limit (according to ASTM-D1754 standard the limit is 1%). The lowest mass loss of 0.09% is achieved by adding nanoZnO particles, nano-TiO2 particles and SBS to base asphalt, which decreases by 86% compared with that of base asphalt. The penetration ratio of base asphalt is improved greatly after being modified, especially the penetration ratio reached to 85% when nano-CaCO3 particles and SBR are added to SK-70 base asphalt. The ductilities of base asphalt and nano-particles/polymer modified asphalts are compared before and after TFOT tests. For SK-70 base asphalt, the ductility completely lost after TFOT tests. However, the ductil-
ities of 1#, 7# and 8# modified asphalts decrease by 48.3%, 75.9% and58.4%, respectively.
From the above analysis, it can be concluded that nanoparticles/polymer modified asphalts present better anti-aging property than SK-70 base asphalt. Especially, the 7# modified asphalt exhibits the highest penetration ratio and ductility after TFOT in the three formulations.
3.2.3. DSR and BBR analysis
(1) DSR analysis The complex shear moduli (G⁄), phase angles (d) and rutting factors (G⁄/sind) of SK-70 base asphalt and modified asphalts at five temperatures (64 C, 70 C, 76 C, 82 C and 88 C) are shown in Figs. 2–4. It should be noted that these three parameters of base asphalt at 76 C cannot meet the specification requirements, so it is not necessary to conduct DSR test at 82 C and 88 C for the base asphalt anymore.
As shown in Fig. 2 the complex shear moduli of nano-particles/ polymer modified asphalts are significantly greater than that of base asphalt at same temperature. Especially, the G⁄ of nanoZnO/SBS modified asphalt is the highest, which increases by 6.6 times compared to that of base asphalt.
Fig. 3 clearly indicates that the phase angles of nano-particles/ polymer modified asphalts are lower than that of base asphalt at same temperature. The phase angles of modified asphalts tend to increase with the increase of temperature at first, and then tend to decrease with the increase of temperature. Whereas, the phase angle of base asphalt increases from 84.32 to 87.63 as the temperature increases from 64 C to 76 C. The different changes of phase angles of modified asphalt and SK-70 base asphalt along with temperatures are due to that nano-particles increase the elastic component of asphalt. So, the loss of elastic modulus in modified asphalt decreases during DSR test, which improves the antishear ability of asphalt.
Fig. 4 displays that the G⁄/sind value of any kind of nanoparticles/polymer modified asphalts is significantly greater than that of base asphalt at same temperature. The rutting factor of SK-70 base asphalt at 76 C is 0.871 kPa which is below the limit (1.0 kPa) provided by AASHTO. However, the rutting factors of nano-particles/polymer modified asphalts at 88 C are all above the limit. Therefore, nano-particles/polymer modified asphalts exhibit better rutting resistance than base asphalt.
(2) BBR analysis
Figs. 5 and 6 present the creep stiffness moduli and creep curve slopes of base asphalt and modified asphalts at three temperatures of 12 C, 18 C and 24 C. Obviously, as the temperature decreased, the creep stiffness modulus increased and the creep curve slope decreased. As we all know, the lower creep stiffness modulus and the higher creep curve slope, the better low temperature properties. Therefore, the results of BBR tests indicate that nano-particles/polymer modified asphalts exhibit better resistance to low temperature cracking than base asphalt. Especially, the nano-ZnO/SBS formulation exhibits the best improvement of SK70 base asphalt in low temperature properties.
3.2.4. Micro-morphology and modification mechanism analysis
(1) SEM analysis From the SEM tests, images of SK-70 base asphalt, SBS modified asphalt, SBR modified asphalt, nano-particles/polymer modified asphalts are shown in Fig. 7. The morphology of base asphalt is homogeneous under microscope (see Fig. 7(a)), but the SEM images (see Fig. 7(b) and (c)) of SBS and SBR modified asphalts show both of these two polymers disperse in base asphalt at the morphology of floccules and with small concentration, which

implies SBS and SBR are difficult to disperse into asphalt. This incompatibility suggests that pure SBS or SBR modified asphalt has poor stability. However, the morphologies of 1#, 7# and 8# modified asphalts show that both polymers and nano-materials particles disperse uniformly in base asphalt, and these particles seem to have been integrated into base asphalt.
When polymer was added to asphalt, it absorbs low molecular oil fraction of asphalt. As a result, the separation between asphaltene and resin to some extent was caused and the degree of association of resin in base asphalt was enhanced. Therefore, the SEM images of SBS modified asphalt and SBR modified asphalt exhibited inhomogeneous morphologies. In addition, the quite big particle size and uneven dispersion of polymer in base asphalt resulted in the bad thermal storage stability. However, the morphology of polymer modified asphalt changed greatly when nano-particles were added, which was attributed to the nanoscale phenomena of nano-particles, such as large active surface area, high surface energy and quantum effects etc. On one hand, nano-particles with high surface energy and active surface area had strong binding capacity to asphalt, and it had a good dispersion in base asphalt. And the alignment film was created between polymer and asphalt when nano-particles were added to polymer modified asphalt, which decreased the interfacial tension between polymer and asphalt, and weakened the aggregation of polymer. Then, the dispersion of polymer in asphalt was improved and the thermal storage stability was enhanced. Moreover, the interfacial structure occurred between nano-particles and polymer as well as between nano-particles and asphalt. The interface could inhibit the movement of macromolecular chains of polymer and asphalt, and could reduce the extension of micro-crack in asphalt in service. Therefore, the mechanical strength, anti-fatigue performance and fracture toughness of asphalt were improved a lot.
(2) FTIR analysis
FTIR spectra for base asphalt, SBS modified asphalt, SBR modified asphalt, 1#, 7# and 8# nano-particles/polymer modified asphalts samples show the characteristic vibration from asphalt and different modifiers. The transmission FTIR spectra of nanoZnO/TiO2/SBS, nano-ZnO/SBS, and nano-CaCO3/SBS modified asphalts in the region of 500–4000 cm 1 are normalized for easier comparison, which are shown in Figs. 8–10.
In the FTIR spectrum of the base SK-70 asphalt, the strong peaks within 2900–3000 cm 1 region are typical CAH stretching vibration in aliphatic chains. The peak at 1450–1500 cm 1 is attributed to C@C stretching vibration in aromatics. The CAH symmetric deforming in CH3 and CAH asymmetric deforming in CH3 and CH2 are observed at 2850 cm 1 and 1400 cm 1, respectively. The small peaks within 650–910 cm 1 region are typical CAH vibration of benzene. These band assignment of C@H stretching, CAH out-ofplane bending, CAH asymmetric bending and CAH asymmetric stretching from SK-70 base asphalt are consistent with the findings of other researchers [37–39]. In the FTIR spectra of nano-ZnO, the peaks around 3400 cm 1 and 446 cm 1 are typical –OH stretching vibration and Zn-O stretching vibration from nano-ZnO particles, respectively. The peaks around 2600 cm 1 and 1400 cm 1 are attributed to CAH asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration, which come from silane coupling agent. In the FTIR spectra of nano-TiO2, the peaks around 1200 cm 1 and 500 cm 1 are –OH bending vibration and Ti-O-Ti vibration from nano-TiO2 particles. In the FTIR spectra of nano-CaCO3, the peaks around 2500 cm 1 and 1400 cm 1 are contributed by CAO stretching vibration and bending vibration from nano-CaCO3 particles.
Compared to the FTIR spectrum of base asphalt, no additional peaks occur in the FTIR spectra of SBS or SBR modified asphalt, and the peak around 700 cm 1 in polymer modified asphalt disappears due to the split of C@C bond of polybutadiene in polymer. Therefore, the FTIR results of base asphalt and polymer modified asphalt imply that physical reaction play the dominant role in modification process of pure polymer modified asphalts. It can be seen from Figs. 8 and 9 that new peaks appear around 2700 cm 1 and 1000 cm 1 for asphalt binders modified with nano-ZnO and nano-TiO2, and the peak around 700 cm 1 disappears. The changes of peaks imply that chemical reactions occur between base asphalt and nano-materials. From Fig. 10, it can be seen that new peaks around 1000 cm 1 and 1700 cm 1 appear, and these changes are caused by the chemical reaction between base asphalt and the hydroxyl of modified nano-material.
Therefore, the modification mechanism of nano-particles/ polymer modified asphalt is very complicated. The physical and chemical reactions in nano-particles/polymer modified asphalt might significantly alter the structure of base asphalt, and result in excellent mechanics and mechanical properties of modified asphalt.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In order to improve the high and low temperature properties of SK-70 base asphalt, in this study, several materials including nanoZnO, nano-TiO2, nano-CaCO3, SBS and SBR were chosen as modifiers. The optimal modification systems were proposed to modify SK-70 base asphalt. The high and low temperature properties of the optimal modified asphalts were studied. SEM test was conducted to study the morphology of modified asphalt. And the FTIR test was conducted to evaluate the interaction between modifiers and asphalt. The main findings and conclusions are as follows:
1. Three optimal modification systems including 3% nano-ZnO + 0.5% nano-TiO2 + 3.7%SBS, 5% nano-ZnO + 4.2%SBS, 5% nanoCaCO3 + 4%SBR were proposed to modify SK-70 base asphalt. 2. The ductility and softening point tests of optimal modified asphalts show that the ductility of 5% nano-CaCO3 + 4%SBR modified asphalt reaches above 100 cm, the softening point of 5% nano-ZnO + 4.2%SBS modified asphalt increases by 30 C compared to SK-70 base asphalt. The aging test shows that the proposed modified asphalts present better anti-aging property than SK-70 base asphalt. Furthermore, the 5%nano-ZnO + 4%SBS modified asphalt exhibits the best anti-aging ability in the three modification systems. The DSR test indicates that all of the three optimal modified asphalts present greater complex shear modulus and rutting factor, lower phase angle compared with those of SK-70 asphalt. The BBR test shows that 5% nano-ZnO + 4%SBS modification formulation exhibits the best improvement effect on anti-rutting and anti-cracking abilities of SK-70 base asphalt in three modification systems. 3. The morphology of the modified asphalts shows that the nanomaterials can increase the compatibility between asphalt and polymer and then can improve the dispersibility of polymer in asphalt. The FTIR tests indicate that the physical reaction plays the dominant role in the modification process for the pure polymer modified asphalt, and both physical reaction and chemical reaction occur in the modification process for the nanoparticles/polymer modified asphalts.

metadata.abstractText: At present, most asphalts and modified asphalts cannot meet requirements of both high temperature stability and low temperature cracking resistance simultaneously. Hence, the objective of this paper is to find new modification system to improve the high and low temperature properties of SK-70 base asphalt. In this paper, nano-zinc oxide (nano-ZnO) particles, nano-titanium dioxide (nano-TiO2) particles, nano-calcium carbonate (nano-CaCO3) particles, styrene-butadiene-styrene (SBS) and styrene-butadienerubber (SBR) were selected as modifiers. The modified asphalt samples with three or two kinds of modifiers were prepared, and the softening point, ductility and penetration of modified asphalt samples were measured and compared. Eventually, three optimal nano-particles/polymer modification systems for SK-70 base asphalt including 3%nano-ZnO/0.5%nano-TiO2/3.7%SBS, 5%nano-ZnO/4.2%SBS, 5%nanoCaCO3/4%SBR were proposed. To study the effects of these three optimal modification formulations on high and low temperature properties of base asphalt, dynamic shear rheometer (DSR), thin film oven test (TFOT), and beam bending rheometer (BBR) tests were conducted on the asphalt of SK-70 and the nanoparticles/polymer modified asphalts. The micro-morphology of SK-70 and the modified asphalts was examined using scanning electron microscope (SEM) and the reactions between modifiers and SK-70 base asphalt were studied by infrared spectrum instrument. From the test results, it was observed that the nano-materials were well dispersed in base asphalt, and could increase the dispersibility of polymer in base asphalt and improve the compatibility between polymer and base asphalt. Furthermore, the nano-materials could improve the high and low temperature properties of SK-70 base asphalt. Additionally, the results also revealed that for polymer modified asphalts the physical reaction between polymers and asphalt played the dominant role in the modification process, while for nano-particles/ polymer modified asphalts, both physical and chemical reaction occurred in the modification process. 2016 Published by Elsevier Ltd.
